question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the median number of moons per planet? (Include Pluto, although arguments rage on about Pluto's status...) \begin{tabular}{c|c}
Planet & $\#$ of Moons\\
\hline
Mercury&0\\
Venus &0\\
Earth &1\\
Mars &2\\
Jupiter&16\\
Saturn&23\\
Uranus&15\\
Neptune&2\\
Pluto&5\\
\end{tabular}
inference:
1. Order the data set from least to greatest:\newline
0, 0, 1, 2, 2, 5, 15, 16, 23\newline
2. With an odd number of values in the data set, the median is the middle value:\newline
0, 0, 1, 2, 2, 5, 15, 16, 23\newline
3. The middle value is 2.\newline
Final Answer: $\boxed{2}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We put the numbers in order: $0\ 0\ 1\ 2\ 2\ 5\ 15\ 16\ 23.$ To find the median, we find the middle value that separates the lower and upper halves of the data. There are $9$ planets, so the $5^\text{th}$ value will be the median (there are $4$ values below and $4$ values above the $5^\text{th}$ value). The median is $\boxed{2}.$

ground_truth: We put the numbers in order: $0\ 0\ 1\ 2\ 2\ 5\ 15\ 16\ 23.$ To find the median, we find the middle value that separates the lower and upper halves of the data. There are $9$ planets, so the $5^\text{th}$ value will be the median (there are $4$ values below and $4$ values above the $5^\text{th}$ value). The median is $\boxed{2}.$
